newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai parliament approves 1996/97 budget bill.
newsitem.headline: Thai parliament approves 1996/97 budget bill.

text.p: The Thai parliament approved the budget for the 1996/97 fiscal year after seven days of sometimes heated debate, officials said on Wednesday.
The House of Representatives early on Wednesday voted 199 to 115 for the record 984-billion-baht ($39.36-billion) budget for the fiscal year starting October 1, parliament officials said.
The balanced budget projects government spending to rise 16.7 percent in fiscal 1996/97 from the previous year.
The bill will be forwarded to the appointed Senate later on Wednesday for endorsement.

The bill received only three votes more than the majority needed for passage by the 391-member lower House, and the narrowness of the approval showed the instability of the 13-month old coalition government, a political analyst said.
Questions have been raised about the future of Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa's government since the third largest member, the Palang Dharma Party (PDP), quit the coalition last week.

The PDP pullout left a six-party coalition with 209 seats and a slim majority in parliament, and rivalry within Banharn's own Chart Thai party and threats of more coalition partners leaving have raised doubts about the government's stability.
The six remaining parties vowed to stick together at least until the budget bill was passed.

The government now faces a no-confidence debate. Opposition parties submitted a no-confidence motion on Tuesday, accusing Banharn of mismanagement and inefficiency, and debate on the measure is tentatively scheduled to begin on September 11.
